data.question: What is the primary material used in the fabrication of the 3D printed reactors discussed in the text?
Which two metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were successfully synthesized using the 3D printed reactors, as mentioned in the text?
What is the maximum operating temperature mentioned for the 3D printed reactors before the polypropylene begins to soften?
How were the reactant mixtures introduced into the 3D printed reactors during their fabrication?
data.answer: The reactor fabrication process was automatically paused after the print was 80% complete to allow the introduction of the appropriate reaction mixtures, then printing was restarted to complete the reactor.

data.question: What new coordination polymers were discovered using the high-throughput 3D printed reactor arrays?
What was the purpose of creating a 5x5 array of 1 mL capacity reaction chambers in one of the reactor designs?
data.answer: To allow high-throughput hydrothermal investigation of reaction systems, suitable for screening 25 simultaneous, discovery-scale reactions per device.

data.question: What was the outcome when using the 3D printed reactors to synthesize MIL-96 compared to traditional apparatus?
data.answer: The yields were comparable; 60% from the 3D printed reactor compared with 65% from the traditional apparatus.

data.question: How did the researchers ensure safety when conducting high-temperature reactions in the 3D printed reactors?
data.answer: Appropriate safety equipment and secondary containment were used at all times.

data.question: What was the main advantage of using 3D printing technology for creating reactors according to the text?
data.answer: It allows the production of varying scales of devices and the ability to reconfigure designs easily, cheaply, and quickly based on exact experimental requirements.

data.question: How did the use of 3D printed reactors compare to traditional hydrothermal synthesis equipment in terms of cost?
data.answer: 3D printed reactors are an economical alternative due to the low cost of materials and the ability to produce an unlimited number of identical reactors after the initial outlay on 3D printing equipment.

data.question: What was the significance of the discovery of [Cu(L5-2 H)(P3)]n and [Cd(L5-2 H)(P3)]n using 3D printed reactors?
data.answer: It demonstrated the utility of 3D printed, high-throughput array reactors in discovering new materials and optimizing their synthesis.

data.question: What future developments are being investigated for 3D printed reactors according to the text?
data.answer: Developing polymers that can take an active role in reactions, adding nanoparticle catalysts in the polymer walls, and investigating additional surface modifications to aid crystallization.

data.question: True or False: The 3D printed reactors can only be used for hydrothermal synthesis at temperatures below 100 degrees Celsius.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors are reusable and do not require destruction to retrieve synthesized materials.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors were only capable of synthesizing known MOFs, not discovering new coordination polymers.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors can be used with a variety of solvents, including aqueous and aqueous/DMF systems.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors have fixed volumes and cannot be designed for different scales of synthesis.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors are made from a material that begins to soften at approximately 200 degrees Celsius.
True or False: The high-throughput 3D printed reactor arrays allow for the screening of up to 25 simultaneous reactions.
True or False: The 3D printed reactors have shown to be less effective in yield and purity of products compared to traditional hydrothermal synthesis equipment.
